user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of get_rq_uname_type:
```c
_MHD_static_inline enum MHD_DigestAuthUsernameType
get_rq_uname_type (const struct MHD_RqDAuth *params)
{
  if (NULL != params->username.value.str)
  {
    if (NULL == params->username_ext.value.str)
      return params->userhash ?
             MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_USERHASH :
             MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_STANDARD;
    else  /* Both 'username' and 'username*' are used */
      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_INVALID;
  }
  else if (NULL != params->username_ext.value.str)
  {
    if (! params->username_ext.quoted && ! params->userhash &&
        (MHD_DAUTH_EXT_PARAM_MIN_LEN <= params->username_ext.value.len) )
      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_EXTENDED;
    else
      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_INVALID;
  }

  return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_MISSING;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function get_rq_uname_type:
struct MHD_RqDAuth
{
  struct MHD_RqDAuthParam nonce;
  struct MHD_RqDAuthParam opaque;
  struct MHD_RqDAuthParam response;
  struct MHD_RqDAuthParam username;
  struct MHD_RqDAuthParam username_ext;
  struct MHD_RqDAuthParam realm;
  struct MHD_RqDAuthParam uri;
  /* The raw QOP value, used in the 'response' calculation */
  struct MHD_RqDAuthParam qop_raw;
  struct MHD_RqDAuthParam cnonce;
  struct MHD_RqDAuthParam nc;

  /* Decoded values are below */
  bool userhash; /* True if 'userhash' parameter has value 'true'. */
  enum MHD_DigestAuthAlgo3 algo3;
  enum MHD_DigestAuthQOP qop;
}
...
#define MHD_DAUTH_EXT_PARAM_MIN_LEN MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_(MHD_DAUTH_EXT_PARAM_PREFIX"'")
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The only potential 8.13 issues arise where the code accesses pointer members of the (const) params structure (.value.str). These lines use those pointer members and should be checked to determine whether the pointed-to data should be const-qualified (e.g., value.str should be declared as const char * if immutable). Other fragments do not need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13: the function parameter is already a pointer to const struct (const struct MHD_RqDAuth *params), boolean and enum members (userhash, quoted, enums) are not pointer types, length comparisons (.value.len) and macro uses are not pointer-to-object qualifications, and the return statements and control flow do not involve non-const pointer targets. If further confirmation is required, the definition of struct MHD_RqDAuthParam (specifically the declaration of value.str) should be reviewed, but the code lines listed above are the places where non-const pointer use appears in the provided code.
